skill.name: event-store-design
skill.description: Design and implement event stores for event-sourced systems. Use when building event sourcing infrastructure, choosing event store technologies, or implementing event persistence patterns.
skill.summary: Design and implement event stores for event-sourced systems. Use when building event sourcing infras...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Reviewed three text files totaling 635 lines. The content is documentation with example schemas and code snippets, and it contains no executable scripts or tool integrations.

content.user_title: Design robust event stores for event sourcing
content.value_statement: Event sourced systems fail without durable, ordered storage and clear access patterns. This skill guides you through schemas, storage options, and subscription design.
actual_capabilities: Explain event store requirements and architecture patterns
Provide a PostgreSQL schema for events, snapshots, and checkpoints
Show an async Python event store template for append and read
Demonstrate EventStoreDB client usage and subscriptions
Outline a DynamoDB table design and access pattern
List best practices and anti patterns for event stores
limitations: Does not deploy or configure infrastructure
Does not provide production security hardening
Code examples are templates and require adaptation
Does not model business domains or aggregates

use_cases.title: Choose a storage backend
use_cases.description: Compare EventStoreDB, PostgreSQL, Kafka, and DynamoDB for an event sourced service.

use_cases.title: Design event store schema
use_cases.description: Define tables, indexes, and checkpointing for a new event sourced domain.

use_cases.title: Review implementation plan
use_cases.description: Validate concurrency, ordering, and scaling choices before delivery.

prompt_templates.title: Event store basics
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the core requirements of an event store and how stream ordering works.

prompt_templates.title: PostgreSQL schema
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a PostgreSQL schema with tables and indexes for events, snapshots, and subscription checkpoints.

prompt_templates.title: Async Python template
prompt_templates.prompt: Outline a Python async event store class with append, read stream, and read all methods.

prompt_templates.title: Scale and optimize
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend strategies for scaling reads, subscriptions, snapshots, and global ordering in a large event store.

output_examples.input: Design a PostgreSQL event store for an Order service
output: Tables for events, snapshots, and subscription checkpoints
Indexes for stream queries, global position, and time filters
Guidance on optimistic concurrency and idempotency

best_practices: Use stream identifiers that include aggregate type
Implement optimistic concurrency checks for writes
Store correlation and causation metadata for tracing
anti_patterns: Updating or deleting events after append
Storing large payloads in event data

faq.question: Which platforms can use this skill?
faq.answer: It applies to EventStoreDB, PostgreSQL, DynamoDB, and similar systems across languages.

faq.question: What are the limits of the guidance?
faq.answer: It provides templates and patterns, not full production deployment or security hardening.

faq.question: Can it integrate with existing databases?
faq.answer: Yes, it shows patterns for PostgreSQL and DynamoDB that can be adapted to current stacks.

faq.question: Does it access or store my data?
faq.answer: No, it only provides documentation and example code snippets.

faq.question: What if I see concurrency conflicts?
faq.answer: Check expected version logic, stream ordering, and retry strategy for optimistic concurrency.

faq.question: How is it different from general database advice?
faq.answer: It focuses on event immutability, ordering, and subscriptions specific to event sourcing.
